bibl.title: Letter from Cornelia Knox Kean to Philip Showalter Hench and Mary Hench, February 6, 1942

div1.p: Kean expresses appreciation to Mary and Philip Hench for an enjoyable evening. She informs them that Jefferson Randolph Kean is in the hospital but improving.

div1.head: Letter from Cornelia Knox Kean to Philip Showalter Hench and Mary Hench, February 6, 1942
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D.C.
February 6, 1942
Dear Doctor and Mrs. Hench:
div1.p:
It was in my heart to write
you after our charming and interesting
evening with you, and thank you for
the pleasure you had given us in
being with you and Mrs. Hench, but
I hope you will for give me where I
tell you that general Kean has
been ill and is at Walter Reed
Hospital. He is better now, and
AC
K
I hope will be home next week.
He had a sudden recurrence of
the illness he had last May.
But we recognized the symptoms
and got the Doctor early in
the morning and took him on a
stretcher to the Hospital. I
am grateful that he is where
he gets the devoted care and
skill. They gave him one of
the Sulphanilamides (?) and
after some days of painful
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
explorations, they have stopped
the treatments and he feels better.

It was a disappointment to us
that we could not ask you to
dine with us, as we had
planned to do before General
Kean went to the hospital at
the time of your visit in
Washington. But I hope this
may be a pleasure deferred.

AC
K
Your letter of February 3 rd
has come. I will take it to
General Kean at the hospital.
He is well enough now to be
interested in all that you
write him. You are an in-
spiration to him. It is such
interests that make his life beauti-
ful and keeps him young in
spirit.

With kind remembrance to
you both, believe me.
